title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0001
text: What is the main principle of the Database per Service pattern in microservices?

options.text: Each microservice owns its own database
All microservices share a single database
Databases are managed by a central team

explanation: In the Database per Service pattern, each microservice has its own database to ensure loose coupling and autonomy.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0002
text: Which of the following is a key benefit of the Database per Service pattern?
explanation: Having separate databases for each service ensures that services are loosely coupled and can evolve independently.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0003
text: Which of the following is a challenge of the Database per Service pattern?
explanation: Cross-service queries and transactions are complex because data is distributed across multiple databases.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0004
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for scalability?

options.text: Each service can scale its database independently
Scaling depends on a central database

explanation: Each service can scale its database independently based on its own workload and performance needs.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0005
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for fault isolation?

options.text: A failure in one service’s database does not affect others

explanation: Each service’s database is isolated, so a failure in one does not impact other services.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0006
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for technology diversity?

options.text: Each service can use the most suitable database technology
All services must use the same database

explanation: The pattern supports polyglot persistence, allowing each service to choose the best database for its needs.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0007
text: Which of the following is a challenge of the Database per Service pattern?
explanation: Maintaining consistency across multiple databases is challenging because distributed transactions are complex.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0008
text: Which of the following patterns helps maintain consistency across services with separate databases?
explanation: The Saga pattern coordinates distributed transactions across services to maintain eventual consistency.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0009
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for team autonomy?

options.text: Teams can manage and deploy their own databases
Teams must coordinate all database changes
Teams depend on a central DBA team

explanation: Each team can manage its own database, improving autonomy and agility.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0010
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for maintainability?

options.text: Changes in one service’s data model do not affect others
All services must update their schemas together

explanation: Each service’s schema is independent, so changes do not impact other services.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0011
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for security?

options.text: Data access can be restricted per service
All services share the same credentials

explanation: Each service can enforce its own security policies and access controls.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0012
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for resilience?

options.text: Recovery depends on a central database

explanation: Each service can recover independently, improving overall system resilience.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0013
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for performance optimization?

options.text: Each service can tune its database for its workload
All services share the same tuning parameters
Performance tuning depends on a central DBA

explanation: Each service can optimize its database independently for its specific performance needs.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0014
text: Which of the following is a challenge of the Database per Service pattern for reporting?
explanation: Reporting across multiple databases is complex because data is distributed.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0015
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for modularity?

options.text: It promotes modular design by isolating data per service
It enforces a single global schema

explanation: Each service’s database isolation supports modular design and domain separation.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0016
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for continuous delivery?

options.text: Each service can deploy database changes independently

explanation: Independent databases allow services to deploy changes without affecting others.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0017
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for innovation?

options.text: Teams can experiment with new database technologies
All teams must use the same database

explanation: Teams can innovate by experimenting with different database technologies suited to their needs.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0018
text: Which of the following is a challenge of the Database per Service pattern for data integrity?
explanation: Referential integrity across services is difficult because data is stored in separate databases.

title: MicroserviceDatabasePerService - Q0019
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Database per Service pattern for data ownership?

options.text: Each service owns and controls its data

explanation: Each service has clear ownership and control over its data, improving accountability.

options.text: Each microservice manages its own database independently
All microservices share a single centralized database
Data is stored in a single monolithic schema
Data is managed by a central data warehouse

explanation: Each microservice owns and manages its own database, ensuring autonomy and loose coupling.
